header.title: Notes on the Study of Later Kabbalah in English: THE SAFED PERIOD & LURIANIC KABBALAH
header.category: Western Esotericism: Jewish Mysticism, Kabbalah, Lurianic Kabbalah, Bibliography

central_thesis: This document provides a comprehensive, albeit brief, overview and bibliography of significant figures, movements, and translated works pertaining to the Safed Period of Kabbalah and the subsequent development of Lurianic Kabbalah in English. It highlights the historical evolution, diverse interpretations, and challenges in the study of these traditions due to limited translated material and varying doctrinal approaches.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces Safed as a flourishing center of Jewish ideals and spirituality in the sixteenth century, highlighting key figures such as Joseph Karo, Moses Cordovero, and Isaac Luria, whose works profoundly influenced Judaism. It provides a general bibliography for the academic study of this period.

This part focuses on Joseph Karo, the renowned legalist and mystic. It lists and describes works by and about him, including his codification of Jewish law, *Shulhan Arukh*, and his mystical diary, *Maggid Mesharim*, which records conversations with a celestial mentor.

This section details the contributions of Moses Cordovero, a late exponent of classical Kabbalah known for systematizing a vast body of lore. It provides a bibliography of his major works such as *Pardes Rimmonim* and the ethical treatise *Tomer Devorah*, noting their philosophical and ethical significance.
This segment highlights Elijah de Vidas and his popular kabbalistic ethical treatise, *Reshith Hokhmah* (The Beginning of Wisdom), providing references to its translations and summaries.

This section introduces Lurianic Kabbalah, emphasizing its pervasive influence and the central role of Isaac Luria, despite his limited writings. It lists notable works that systematically present the basic tenets of Lurianic Kabbalah and cautions about variations and layers upon these teachings.

This part delves into the complexities of defining Lurianic Kabbalah, noting that Luria himself wrote little and that his teachings were primarily recorded by his disciple Hayim Vital in works like *Etz Hayim* and *Shemonah She'arim*. It discusses the differing interpretations and doctrinal developments by other disciples and schools, such as Joseph ibn Tabul, Moses Yonah, and Israel Sarug, particularly concerning concepts like *tzimtzum*.

This section outlines the work of Isaiah Horowitz, a rabbi who integrated traditional rabbinic sources, the Zohar, and teachings from Karo, de Vidas, Cordovero, and Luria into his major work, *Shney Luchot Habrit*, an important piece of Eastern European kabbalistic ethical literature.

This part covers Abraham Herrera, known for his attempts to reconcile Lurianic Kabbalah with Neoplatonic philosophy in *Puerto del Cielo*, and discusses how his work was transmitted and interpreted, notably through Knorr von Rosenroth's *Kabbala denudata*.

This section discusses the igniting of Messianic sparks within the Lurianic complex into the Shabbatean movement, with dogma shaped by Nathan of Gaza and Abraham Miguel Cardozo. It explores the debate around the literal versus symbolic interpretation of *tzimtzum* within this context.

This segment introduces Moses Hayim Luzzatto (RaMHaL), emphasizing his unique role in codifying Kabbalah and incorporating it into daily thought and practice. It lists his key kabbalistic works like *Kelah Pithei Hokhmah*, which systematized his "hermeneutical/visionary" interpretation of Lurianic teachings.

structure_content.chapter_title: Elijah ben Solomon, Gaon of Vilna
structure_content.summary: This part describes Elijah ben Solomon, the Gaon of Vilna (GRA), a kabbalist who rejected Hasidism as pantheistic heresy. His kabbalistic commentaries are characterized by an eclectic allegorical approach, drawing from the entire Kabbalistic tradition.

This section focuses on Shneur Zalman of Lyady, founder of HABAD Hasidism, whose influential work *Tanya* condenses Lurianic Kabbalah and Hasidic interpretations into a systematic theosophy and ethics for the broader Jewish community.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bet El, Shalom Sharabi, & Yosef Hayim b. Elijah al-Hakam of Baghdad
structure_content.summary: This part describes the Bet El school, founded by Shalom Mizrahi Sharabi (RaShaSh), which adhered closely to Vital's *Shemonah She'arim* and emphasized *kavvanot* and mystical contemplation. It also mentions Yosef Hayim b. Elijah (Ben Ish Hai) and his integration of halakha with kabbalah.
This segment introduces Yitshak Ayzik Haver Wildmann, a Lithuanian kabbalist influenced by the GRA and Ramhal, known for his extensive Lurianic commentary *Pithei Shearim*.

This section details Yehuda Lev Ashlag's significant contributions, including his translation of the entire Zohar into Hebrew with Luria-based commentary (*Ha Sulam*) and his extensive commentary on Vital's *Etz Hayim* (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*), noting his foundational role for modern Kabbalistic schools.

This concluding section lists general articles and books related to the study of later Kabbalah, covering diverse topics from comparative Kabbalistic systems to Manasseh ben Israel, Jewish exorcism, and the problem of evil in Kabbalah.

key_concepts.definition: A major center of Jewish ideals and spirituality in the sixteenth century, where law, ethics, philosophy, and mysticism flourished, and groundbreaking Kabbalistic developments occurred.
The last major religious movement in Judaism, shaped primarily by Isaac Luria and recorded by Hayim Vital, which became highly influential across all sections of the Jewish people and Diaspora.
A fundamental Lurianic concept referring to the divine self-contraction, subject to ongoing debate among Kabbalists regarding its literal versus symbolic (allegorical/philosophical) interpretation.
Joseph Karo's diary of his conversations with a celestial mentor, providing insights into his mystical experiences.
Moses Cordovero's major work, a comprehensive systematic theology of classical Kabbalah, constituting an epitome of kabbalistic lore.
Moses Cordovero's kabbalistic ethical treatise, focusing on the doctrine of the imitation of God as expressed in the ten sefirot.
Hayim Vital's foundational work, based largely on notes from his direct contact with Isaac Luria, comprising Luria's major teachings.
A later arrangement and expansion of Hayim Vital's work, systematizing Luria's teachings, which remained in manuscript form for centuries.
The central figure of a messianic movement (1626-1676) whose dogma and myth were significantly shaped by Lurianic doctrine and terminology.
A Hasidic movement founded by Shneur Zalman of Lyady, known for its systematic theosophy and ethics, which condenses Lurianic Kabbalah and Hasidic interpretations.
Mystical contemplations or intentions, particularly emphasized in the prayer practices of the Bet El school of Kabbalah.
Yehuda Lev Ashlag's comprehensive Hebrew translation of the Zohar, embedded with his own Luria-based commentary.

key_concepts.term: Talmud Eser Sefirot (Study of the Ten Sefirot)
key_concepts.definition: Yehuda Lev Ashlag's extensive commentary on Hayim Vital's *Etz Hayim*, a significant work for modern Kabbalistic study.

practical_system.description: This document does not present a practical system itself but rather provides a scholarly overview and comprehensive bibliography of academic and translated works that discuss various Kabbalistic systems, their philosophies, and associated practical elements. It outlines the historical evolution of Kabbalistic practices from the Safed period through Lurianic traditions, Hasidism, and modern interpretations, pointing to source material for those interested in operative Kabbalah.
tools: Sacred texts and commentaries: *Shulhan Arukh*, *Maggid Mesharim*, *Pardes Rimmonim*, *Tomer Devorah*, *Reshith Hokhmah*, *Etz Hayim*, *Shemonah She'arim*, *Shney Luchot Habrit*, *Puerto del Cielo*, *Kelah Pithei Hokhmah*, *Tanya*, *Sidur Rehovot ha-Nahar*, *Ha Sulam*, *Talmud Eser Sefirot*.
Diagrams and visual aids for understanding Lurianic doctrine, such as Poppers' *Ilan ha-Gadol* (Tree of Greatness).
Scholarly analyses and bibliographies (like this document) for contextualizing and navigating the vast body of Kabbalistic literature.
rituals: The practice of 'mystical piety' as codified by Safed mystics (Cordovero, Luria, Karo) and integrated into daily life.
Techniques of mystical meditation for achieving prophecy and the Holy Spirit, as taught by Isaac Luria and Hayim Vital.
Theurgical contemplation through *Yihudim* (unifications) in Lurianic Kabbalah.
Kabbalistic ethical practices focused on the imitation of God through the sefirot, as detailed in *Tomer Devorah* and *Reshith Hokhmah*.
Mystical prayer, including the emphasis on *kavvanot* (intentions) in the school of Shalom Sharabi and Bet El.
Lurianic observances as codified by Jacob Zemech in *Shulhan Arukh ha-Ari*.
Spirit possession and exorcism, as discussed in works referencing Safed Kabbalists and Lurianic exorcism.

relevant_quotes.text: The Lurianic Kabbalah was the last religious movement in Judaism the influence of which became preponderant among all sections of Jewish people and in every country of the Diaspora, without exception.

Defining Lurianic Kabbalah presents several problems, not the least of which is that Luria wrote very little and did not leave a systematic exposition of his own teachings. Among the first—and certainly the most important—to do so was Luria's student in Safed, Hayim Vital (1542-1620), a kabbalist and occultist of some experience and reputation before becoming Luria's pupil.
It may well be that the Sabateans were the first ... it served their mythical/antinomian agenda

One must not be misled by the common terminology and mistake it for identity in meaning or conceptual unity. The Hasidic movement made extensive use of the framework of the Kabbalistic tradition as a basis for the legitimization of its freedom to innovate in religious thought and as grounds for permission to formulate new spiritual priorities.

critical_analysis.relevance: This document is highly relevant for anyone studying the historical development and academic literature of Jewish Kabbalah from the 16th century onwards, especially regarding the Safed and Lurianic traditions. It serves as an invaluable guide to available English translations and scholarly analyses, highlighting the complexities, divergences, and intellectual lineages within these esoteric movements. Its emphasis on the lack of translated material underscores an ongoing challenge in the field, making it a critical resource for advanced research.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Academic researchers, students of Jewish mysticism, practitioners of Kabbalah seeking historical and textual grounding, and anyone interested in a comprehensive English-language bibliography of later Kabbalah and its historical context.
